title: How can an introvert make friends? - Quora

response.answer_text: Hey, nice to meet you. My name’s Jet Pack. I’m basically a social caterpillar that made his wings out of duct tape, and now I pride myself with the ability to make friends with just about anyone at just about anytime. While socializing comes easily to extroverts, for introverted people, it can be more challenging. But isn’t that exactly what self-proclaimed introverts enjoy? Challenges and puzzles, obstacles for them to overcome. For me, and hopefully for you, it can become a game, a sport even. While I have way too much information to put in one answer, I can give you a few of my favorite tips that I’ve picked up over the years. Every single thing I suggest doing is something that I’ve tested, and it has worked. Tip #1: do things to prove to yourself that you do not care about other people’s opinions I used to spend a ton of time getting ready for school in the morning because I wanted to look nice for friends/random girl I had a crush on/judgy strangers in the hallways, but one day I was running late. I hurriedly yanked the first pair of pants off of the shelf, and ran to school. When I got to my first class, I saw a couple students looking at me snickering. Instantly, I attacked myself, racking my brain while trying to find the reason for their humor. Was my hair messed up? Was my shirt on backwards? “Hey Jet,” a girl said, “what happened to your pants?” “Uh,” I panicked, and gave the first excuse that popped into my head: “Yeah, my little brother wore these, and he has projectile diarrhea.” I’ll admit, the girl was disgusted, but the rest of the class exploded in laughter. It was at that moment that I realized something: If you just act like you know what you’re doing, you can do basically whatever you want and everyone will think it’s cool. Of course, you won’t be completely judgement free, there will always be metaphorical girls who don’t appreciate poop jokes in your metaphorical classroom, but believe me, it’s worth it. Since then, I’ve done all kinds of things to test the limit of what society will accept. I started wearing pajamas to school, I once came to schopl with a neon green swimcap stretched over my eyebrows. And what I’ve found is this: the more unnacceptable I behave, the more accepted I become Tip #2: Fake it til you make it I arrived at the party. I had had a long day, and I was exhausted, yet my heart was still racing. So many people in such a small space. I had been crying only minutes before from sheer stress overload, and this was not helping. I felt the weight of one thousand sets of eyes crush my confidence. I absolutely could not let them see me cry. Nothing makes me more annoyed than whem people pity me. So I did the only thing I thought would work: lie to everyone. Not with my words, but with my eyes. I jumped and I laughed, I did wierd stupid things with wierd stupid people, even though I felt miserable. But here’s the thing, I didn’t. I don’t remember when exactly, but somewhere along the line, I started to actually have fun, as if I had convinced myself that I wasn’t bitter. There’s an entire science behind this; it’s based off of a priciple called ‘mind body feedback loops’ or ‘power poses’. You can research it if you’d like. It’s incredibly interesting. Tip #3: EVERYONE is a five-year-old, and EVERYONE is you’re long lost brother/sister “Oh my goodness, it’s so good to finally see you again!!! How’s the family?!?” “Oh my goodness! I’m so sorry, but I don’t remember your name.” “No worries dude, we’ve never actually met, but you seem like the kind of guy I would be best friends with.” You know the face a girl makes when they see a five-year-old kid approaching them? That’s the kind of smile you should go for whenever you see someone you want to make a good impression on, because deep down, EVERYONE is a five-year-old kid. We all love sweets and playing pretend, except instead of imagining dragons and castles, we imagine all of the ways things can go wrong any time we open our mouths. You know the way two brothers greet each other after one spends five years touring in Iraq? That should the kind of greeting you give a friend you haven’t seen in a few days. It’s this kind of stuff where if you pretend it long enough, it becomes true. If you pretend that someone is your best friend, it will be true. If you pretend that you are the coolest dude to walk the planet, it will be true. If you pretend that the girl you have a crush on likes you back, it will be true. And don’t give me any shinannigans about becoming ignorant in order to be social. You were going to pretend something anyways. Humans are inevitably irrational and illogical. So if we’re going to convince ourselves of something, it may as well be that we can do anything we want. Which brings me to my final tip: Tip #4: introverts don’t exist This was an insane realization to me. All of the time I had spent being afraid of what others would think of me, all the time I had been mean, spiteful and ignorant in a vain attempt to placate the people around me, all the time I had spent awake at night thinking about the girl I was in love with, the girl I ‘knew’ would never feel the same, all of it was me. I wasn’t predestined to be am introvert. God didn’t add any ‘introvert’ juice into the cauldron when he was making my personality; I did. The only reason I was scared of talking to people was because I didn’t think I could change. I stayed trapped in this prison of anxiety because I thought I’d be lying to myself if I acted brave when I wasn’t. And every time something went wrong, every time I got laughed at, even when I got rejected by the girl, I had a crutch to lean on: It’s because I’m just an introvert. I can’t socialize with people, it’s just not who I am. Scientifically, that doesn’t even make any sense. Humans have been social creatures since before they were even called humans. We have a rediculously large amount of our brain dedicated to being social, making friends, and finding love. The only thing stopping you is yourself, not some stupid latin label. If you want something you’ve never had, you’ll have to do something you’ve never done - Anonymous

Here is the thing with us introverts: We value quality over quantity. Whereas I know many of my extroverted friends value both of them sort of equally, and will inevitably have more friends than me, introverts only need a few good friends we can rely on to keep us from going insane. If you are a true introvert, then you are totally complacent with alone time; in fact, we cherish it! But yes. We do need companionship too and are NOT hermits, despite what others may think. Here are some tips that I used to get quality friends in high school: When you meet someone you think is a quality person and can be a long-time friend, TELL THEMLiterally the first day of school, in grade 8, I met my best friend. I knew he was a quality person and someone that would be compatible with me. In grade 12, for my birthday, he wrote me a letter to tell me he still remembered what I told him 5 years ago when we met. This is verbatim: “I think we will be good friends in the future”This goes with even people you don’t necessarily KNOW, but you FEEL like they are potentially a great person. (You know this because you are a wallflower and have been observing). Use your courage and approach this person and tell them you think they are cool and would love to be their friend. This is EXACTLY how I met my best friend. (Look above)Conversely, if you meet someone who you feel is not compatible with you, and dare I say, someone who is not a quality person, then don’t bother with themIt takes a lot of effort for us introverts to socialize…and we get drained very quickly in these interactionsDon’t bother yourself with people you KNOW won’t be long-lasting friends.With the close friends you do have, please put in some effortI know you don’t want to go to parties. But if it’s a party your friend is throwing, please, please, just show up and offer your time and presence. These little things do add up and your friends will notice, especially if they know you don’t necessarily enjoy partying.Find other introvertsThis is the perfect scenario, because you will have a mutual understanding that even if neither of you contacts each other for days/weeks, you understand that it’s just the introversion acting up. And when you guys do meet up and hang out, the time will be more precious and valuable.Good Luck :)

By staying true to who you are and not feeling like you have to make friends the extroverted way.  Some essentials: Learn to embrace your introversion: The first step to connecting with others is to reconnect with your authentic introverted self. That means being proud of your introversion and comfortable in your way of being. When you do this, you’ll be amazing at how many doors open for you from the world and the people around you.Enjoy your alone time: It’s a tricky balance of making sure we have enough blissful solitude and are giving up a portion in order to be with another. It’s important to decide who is worthy to know our truths. Who will honour the privilege of being accepted into our inner world? Who will treat our thoughts, ideas, and dreams with the respect they deserve? And how can we find them without too much small talk?!Find the right people: It begins with a straightforward question to yourself: What do you actually want to find? Once you get clear on what you want from a friendship and why, you become like a lighthouse to all the friend gems that would have otherwise passed you by. You also begin to notice the right people, and welcome them into your world. (The same principle applies to anything you want in life.) To find the right people you have to be the right person.Energise before you socialise: Meeting new people is best done on a full energy tank. True connection is difficult to cultivate when you feel like you’re about to self-destruct. Know your limits. For some introverts, thirty minutes of meet and greet is fine. For others, ten minutes is too much.Replenish your energy regularly: Understand your energy needs and learn how to honour them without guilt. Sometimes this means saying ‘no’ to certain social activities, so that you can say ‘yes’ to sacred self-care. Sometimes this means getting over the “social hangover” the day after an event by stay in your pyjamas for the next day (or three).Deepen connections the introverted way: Being real, authentic, honest, and truthful is an attractive quality. It draws people in quickly and makes them instantly let their guard down. You remind them that you’re both on the same team here, wanting the same things. One honest admonition can nip small talk in the bud.

If you're a painfully shy introvert like me, it can be very hard to make friends. I find new people utterly terrifying, and will often do anything to keep my discomfort to a minimum; by hiding and only having brief conversations. The friends I do have often ask me “how the hell do you have any friends? XD”. I then point out, “well your my friend ask yourself!”. To be honest then, the friends I have made, are often forced by circumstance. Where I'd be forced to spend extended periods of contact with them. Often wishing to begin with, that they would just go the hell away. But if they're nice people I'll eventually warmup to them, and my tolerance for them grows. I get less and less drained around them. Then I start to enjoy or look forward to there company. At this point I try to actively be there friend. Asking how they're doing, what they're up to. And getting into weirder, more random or deeper conversations. At this point I'm generally also more comfortable with banter and friendly insults. From there I get to meet friend of a friends, with a similar, if just quicker process. As they are affiliated with someone I already like. All in all, I say I've been quite lucky in my social life thus far. I've had people that have initially stuck with me. Through all my discomfort and trying to run away. So I guess the moral of the story is this. Making friends is different for everyone. Some people are the fetchers that go out and pursue friends, and some are passive; where they have a few people that stick to them, long enough to be their friend. And it's OK if you find it hard to actively go out there and make friends, just be in a situation where people could want to stick around and be friends with you. Even you initially don't want them or feel uncomfortable. Good luck!

Expose mutual vulnerability between yourself and someone you'd like to befriend. This self-disclosure fosters a closeness between two people that develops understanding and meaning, two of the key ingredients for friendship.  But, how do we convince people to open up? Checkout some of psychologist Dr. Arthur Aron's 36 questions (listed below) aimed at revealing interpersonal closeness. The next time you're out, challenge yourself to get outside of your comfort zone and ask someone a question from this list. You'll be surprised how receptive people are when you come across as genuinely curious and interested in their answer. After they answer, share your response. You don't have to make it through all 36 questions, but this act is a great gateway to reveal and extend windows of opportunity for friendship. And if you're located in New York City, I've been experimenting with this idea by introducing random people in real life to exchange answers to these questions. Sign up at www.peeps.club if it sounds like something you'd enjoy. Set I 1. Given the choice of anyone in the world, whom would you want as a dinner guest?2. Would you like to be famous? In what way?3. Before making a telephone call, do you ever rehearse what you are going to say? Why?4. What would constitute a “perfect” day for you?5. When did you last sing to yourself? To someone else?6. If you were able to live to the age of 90 and retain either the mind or body of a 30-year-old for the last 60 years of your life, which would you want?7. Do you have a secret hunch about how you will die?8. Name three things you and your partner appear to have in common.9. For what in your life do you feel most grateful?10. If you could change anything about the way you were raised, what would it be?11. Take four minutes and tell your partner your life story in as much detail as possible.12. If you could wake up tomorrow having gained any one quality or ability, what would it be? Set II 13. If a crystal ball could tell you the truth about yourself, your life, the future or anything else, what would you want to know?14. Is there something that you’ve dreamed of doing for a long time? Why haven’t you done it?15. What is the greatest accomplishment of your life?16. What do you value most in a friendship?17. What is your most treasured memory?18. What is your most terrible memory?19. If you knew that in one year you would die suddenly, would you change anything about the way you are now living? Why?20. What does friendship mean to you?21. What roles do love and affection play in your life?22. Alternate sharing something you consider a positive characteristic of your partner. Share a total of five items.23. How close and warm is your family? Do you feel your childhood was happier than most other people’s?24. How do you feel about your relationship with your mother? Set III 25. Make three true “we” statements each. For instance, “We are both in this room feeling ... "26. Complete this sentence: “I wish I had someone with whom I could share ... "27. If you were going to become a close friend with your partner, please share what would be important for him or her to know.28. Tell your partner what you like about them; be very honest this time, saying things that you might not say to someone you’ve just met.29. Share with your partner an embarrassing moment in your life.30. When did you last cry in front of another person? By yourself?31. Tell your partner something that you like about them already.32. What, if anything, is too serious to be joked about?33. If you were to die this evening with no opportunity to communicate with anyone, what would you most regret not having told someone? Why haven’t you told them yet?34. Your house, containing everything you own, catches fire. After saving your loved ones and pets, you have time to safely make a final dash to save any one item. What would it be? Why?35. Of all the people in your family, whose death would you find most disturbing? Why?36. Share a personal problem and ask your partner’s advice on how he or she might handle it. Also, ask your partner to reflect back to you how you seem to be feeling about the problem you have chosen.

As of this moment, there are 1,708 views of this question and only seven answers. Anyone who thinks there is an easy answer to help shy or introverted people make friends is obviously delusional. I've been dealing with this for over 30 years (thanks to parents who uprooted me every other year from school to school). The best way to meet people seems to go somewhere that there are lots of people, but that leads to the phenomenon of finding only previously-established tight-knit cliques who have no interest in finding new people to join them. Over the years, I've forced myself out of my "comfort zone" time and time again, with very little luck. When I've connected with people, it's been random, lending support to the theory that you meet the person you're supposed to when you're not looking. But how is that helpful? I can tell you that the only thing I haven't given up on is meetup dot com.  It certainly isn't the magical answer I thought it would be when I heard about it a year ago, but I've done interesting things and met interesting people. I'm still hoping the right group will come along. I think the great thing about the concept is that it's not just about meeting people who enjoy certain activities (like rock climbing), but there are plenty of groups built around meeting people who share similar views, beliefs, ideals, and tastes. Have you tried craigslist? There are interesting nooks and crannies there that some people don't seem to know about: "strictly platonic" under the  personals section; the community section has stuff like "activities", "classes", "events", "groups", etc; then there are the discussion forums (online forums can be a great way to meet like-minded people, so joining one that's only for your area could increase your chance of developing a bond with someone online that you could actually meet in person!). If it means anything, I think you've got a leg up on most people in our shoes because you're getting out there and you also seem to know what it is about you that makes you "different". Try to keep in mind that there have got to be other "George Carlin types" who enjoy rock climbing, right? On a personal note, I'm really curious why you describe yourself as an "introvert" in your question but in the description you call yourself a "George Carlin type", because I never really got the impression that the guy was introverted!  I think I might be in your shoes though: I'm beyond pessimistic, I swear too much, I am suspicious/unimpressed with religion and dominant cultural norms, etc. Maybe there is a George Carlin fanclub for people like us?

First of all, define introverted. An introverted person is one who is perfectly happy being alone most of the time. This is a person who tends to see social overtures from others as intrusions. A lot of times, people who are socially clumsy sort of pretend to be introverted because they find it a more attractive label. If you wish you had friends and you don’t and you’re lonely, that’s not introversion. It’s social clumsiness. That’s good news, though. Being introverted is a pretty ingrained thing. Being socially clumsy is something that you can address. First, get in shape as much as you can. Then dress well and appropriately. Get clues from what others do. When you see something you admire, try to copy it and incorporate this trait or action into your life. If you feel uncomfortable talking to others, keep it light and don’t talk a lot. If you are considering approaching others, it’s good to approach others who aren’t the life of the party types. Those might be people who turn out to be in a bad mood or who are actual introverts and see your approach as an invasion of sorts. No harm, no foul if that happens. Hang around a few moments and go on to someone else who tends to be at the edges of a gathering. You can do this.

An introvert finds friends like anyone else... by making the effort to connect.  I'm an introvert who has easily moved in excess of 50 times in my 43 years, so learning to make friends has come with practice. I'm quite happily a loner, so making friends hasn't always been high on my list of priorities, but things I have done in the past are:  Try something new on a regular basis (cheesemaking, archery, ice-skating, toastmasters group, whatever) and make the effort to talk to people. If nothing else, you'll expand your life experience and become more interesting because of it.Make the effort to get to know your neighbours. The last town I lived in I made very good friends with 3 sets of neighbours. This weekend I met 2 sets of new neighbours and will be inviting them for a make-your-own-pizza night in the next week.Invite people to a casual gathering (jazz in the park, horse races, local festivals, etc.. whatever works) so there's no pressure to arrange anything yourself (and often you can have a lovely time, even if you're by yourself). Organise a regular (say once a month, or bi-monthly) restaurant meal and invite friends you do have to invite someone new. Organise your own local interest group via social media and arrange a catch-up on a regular basis eg. a thinker's club, book club, car enthusiast club, Scrabble club.. whatever floats your boat.And remember - even if other people have different world-views to you, that doesn't mean you can't be friends. It means you get the opportunity to explore other views and maybe open yourself to new perspectives (or provide that opportunity for others). After all, living in an echo chamber gets pretty boring after a while.

You are in good company as an introvert. At least 1/3 to 1/2 of the population falls into that category. My partner and one of my kids are introverts also. Both graduated HS, College, found a life mate and hold good careers. They also like things that are more solitary pursuits: reading, chess, swimming, skiing, roller skating, surfing, etc. my daughter took violin lessons (private) for 12 plus years. At about age 12, she joined a youth orchestra. She continued for about five or six years. It was an opportunity to be a member of a bigger group but all the prep and performance was individually focused on ones own part.You express interests in rock climbing, hiking, reading, etcetera. I recommend uou join a conservation or land trust group. Those individuals spend a lot of time walking, hiking, enjoying nature. Maybe join a gym that has rock wall climbing. You will probably meet others who share that passion and may enjoy some outdoor adventures like rock or mountain climbing. Book groups are another great way to enjoy your interest in reading but being more in a group setting. If you read a book your passionate about, it's great to share thoughts but book groups tend to let their members participate or listen according up their inclination.I think that once you shed the idea that introverted means alone, you will find pathways to connections. There are connections for everyone once they figure out what they like and want, it is possible to increase the social net. You may never have hoards of followers and friends but, most people don't want that in reality.

When you find yourself in a one on one situation with another person and you have no idea what to say, start with #1 and ask the person, “what are your favourite type of clothes (or fashions)?”. They will respond with some sort of answer. If you also like something that they mention, then great, you have something in common! Next, tell them what you like fashion-wise, and ask their opinion on what you have just said. Keep on until you sense that the other person has nothing much more to say. Now move onto #2 and repeat by asking them their opinion on the historical period that interests you. Continue on with this routine until you reach the end of your list of prepared questions/subjects, remembering to always start by asking them what they think about the subject first. Another way to find favour in the eyes of a person is to often mention their name. So, when you ask them what they think about subject #1, try to phrase the question like this, “Jim/Jane, what do you think about such and such?” Don’t overdo it, but sprinkle in their name every now and then throughout the conversation. Even if you are giving your opinion on a particular subject, always remember that you are seeking to find out what they think about what you are saying? Never argue with them - if they disagree somewhat, then tell them, “That’s an interesting way to look at it, and “I never thought of it that way”. After practicing a few times with different individuals, you’ll find that this method of seeking another’s opinion first starts to come naturally to you and you’ll be much more relaxed when talking to others. One more thing to remember; always be polite by including “please” and “thank you” whenever you are asking others to do something for you, such as in a store. Most people wear name tags - always use them! “Hi, Jim/Jane, would you be so kind as to tell me where I can find such and such?” Wishing you the best on this - I was an introvert, but I became the opposite through using this method. So I tend to approach smaller groups or individuals. I observe them and try to find a meaningful conversation based on their interests, strengths and personality. I use my strength as a listener to analyze what they are saying and respond with a meaningful response that shows I'm interested in them and their interests, not just myself. That being said, if I don’t think someone has value to my life or I have something to offer them, I don’t waste my time. I’m not looking for people just to say I have friends, I value deep relationships and strive to only have people in my life who truly care for me, and vice versa. Be true to yourself, don’t change who you are and people who are meant to be in your life, will find their way to you.
